texts.shortText: Bizarre and instantly recognizable species with a silvery, scaleless skin, gill openings hidden by a soft operculum, long, pointed upper lobe to tail and a strange fleshy hoe-shaped proboscis extending from the snout. Front of first dorsal fin with a large, mildly-toxic, serrate spine. Males have intromittent organs (claspers) extending behind the pelvic fins, a small claw-like appendage (tentaculum) on the top of the head and an additional retractile clasper in a pouch in front of the pelvic fin.
Up to 122 cm total length and a mass of about 5 kg.

Global: Endemic to Southern Africa.

Local/Regional: Namibia to (rarely) KwaZulu-Natal.

Found on soft substrata from the surf zone to a depth of over 300 m and most common in the SW Cape, where it supports a small fishery. The proboscis is used to detect prey buried in the sediments. Females reach sexual maturity at a length of 46- 50 cm and age of 4 years and males at about 43 cm after 3 years. Longevity about 10 years.
Feeds on a variety of bottom-dwelling invertebrates including bivalves, crustaceans, sea-urchins, gastropods and worms, as well as on fish, particularly gobies and lightfish.

Males grasp the females during copulation and insert small spermatophores with their claspers. Females lay distinctive large, spindle-shaped eggs (up to 23 cm long) that are surrounded a broad, flattened flange and somewhat resemble mango-pips. The eggs are laid two at a time and are left unattached on the sea floor until they hatch. Up to 22 eggs are laid per female each year. Incubation time is 9-12 months and size at birth about 13 cm. Hatched egg cases are often washed ashore where they generate much interest due to their peculiar appearance.
Unmistakable and the only common chimera in the region.
